text: Metal phosphonates with open frameworks or porous structures have received great attention because of their potential applications in adsorption, separation, ion exchange, catalysis, etc.
On the other hand, lanthanide-based compounds are interesting luminescent materials because they could emit over the entire spectral range: near-infrared (Nd
Consequently, design and syntheses of porous lanthanide phosphonates are attractive in developing new materials with multifunctions.

To prepare lanthanide phosphonates with open framework or porous structures, one efficient approach is using phosphonate ligands with additional functional groups such as a second phosphonate or carboxylate group. Thus, by using
were obtained which show open framework structures in which the inorganic chains composed of corner-sharing {LaO

-sulfophenylphosphonic acid) were also obtained which contain tetranuclear cluster units interconnected by the same phosphonate ligand (H
With regard to compounds containing both phosphonate and carboxylate groups, Pr
provides the first open framework lanthanide carboxyphosphonate, where one-dimensional (1D) inorganic chains made up of corner- and edge-sharing {PrO
O (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy, Y, Er, Yb, Lu), based on N-(phosphonomethyl)iminodiacetic anion (H
PMIDA), are reported which exhibit three-dimensional (3D) open framework structures with helical tunnels.
The reactions of 1-phosphonomethylproline with lanthanide salts result in chiral porous compounds Ln[(
O (Ln = Tb, Dy, Eu, Gd) built from 1D triple-strand helical chains.
A few lanthanide oxalatophosphonates with open framework structures are also described.
In this paper, we describe four new isostructural lanthanide carboxyphosphonates Ln(O
)]. All exhibit open framework structures containing parallelogram-like channels.

Unconventional metal organic frameworks: porous cross-linked phosphonates

A review.  The past decade has witnessed an exponential growth of metal org. framework compds. (MOFs).  The defining character of these compds. is their porosity.  However, in many cases no effort was made to show evidence that a stable porous structure was achieved and that the pores may be accessed.  The authors describe recent work on porous pillared zirconium diphosphonates, and the newer and in many respects different characteristics of tin(iv) phosphonates.  The Sn(iv) monophosphonates form spherical globules that exhibit very high surface areas.  The surface area arises from their nano-sized particles that pack in a house of cards arrangement.  Also, the 1,4-monophenyldiphosphonic acid forms highly porous (250-400 m2 g-1) materials with Sn(iv) when prepd. in alc.-water media.  This is not the case with analogous Zr(iv) compds.  The many variations in the syntheses of both the zirconium and tin aryl- and alkyldiphosphonate pillars and their combinations with spacers such as Me- and monophenylphosphonic acid have created a variety of highly porous materials that are stable to 400° in air, highly stable in acid media, do not collapse when de-solvated, and can be post and presynthesis altered to include functional groups.  Several new directions taken by other researchers are also described.  However, it is emphasized in this presentation that the cross-linked compds. form particles that ppt. rapidly into nanoparticles that exhibit only short range order.  Therefore, they differ from the more conventional MOFs in that they are not amenable to structure soln. by x-ray or neutron diffraction techniques.  Rather, they must be understood from modeling and indirect data from EM, NMR, and addnl. spectroscopic and textural studies.
Hybrid porous solids: past, present, future

A review.  This crit. review will be of interest to the experts in porous solids (including catalysis), but also solid state chemists and physicists.  It presents the state-of-the-art on hybrid porous solids, their advantages, their new routes of synthesis, the structural concepts useful for their 'design', aiming at reaching very large pores.  Their dynamic properties and the possibility of predicting their structure are described.  The large tunability of the pore size leads to unprecedented properties and applications.  They concern adsorption of species, storage and delivery and the phys. properties of the dense phases. (323 refs.).
Structural Transformations and Adsorption of Fuel-Related Gases of a Structurally Responsive Nickel Phosphonate Metal-Organic Framework, Ni-STA-12

Miller, Stuart R.; Pearce, Gordon M.; Wright, Paul A.; Bonino, Francesca; Chavan, Sachin; Bordiga, Silvia; Margiolaki, Irene; Guillou, Nathalie; Ferey, Gerard; Bourrelly, Sandrine; Llewellyn, Philip L.
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The structure of the Ni N,N'-piperazinebismethylenephosphonate, Ni-STA-12 (St. Andrews porous material-12), was detd. in the hydrated (Ni2L·8H2O, L = O3PCH2NC4H8NCH2PO3), partially dehydrated (Ni2L·2H2O), and fully dehydrated (Ni2L) forms from high-resoln. synchrotron x-ray powder diffraction.  The framework structures of Ni2L·8H2O and Ni2L·2H2O are almost identical (R‾3, a 27.8342(1), c 6.2421(2) Å; R‾3, a 27.9144(1), c 6.1655(2) Å) with addnl. physisorbed H2O of the as-prepd. Ni-STA-12 present in an ordered H-bonded network in the channels.  Ab initio structure soln. of the fully dehydrated solid indicates it has changed symmetry to triclinic (P‾1, a 6.03475(5), b 14.9157(2), c 16.1572(2) Å, α 112.5721(7), β 95.7025(11), γ 96.4950(11)°) as a result of a topotactic structural rearrangement.  The fully dehydrated solid possesses permanent porosity with elliptical channels 8 Å × 9 Å in free diam.  The structural change results from the loss of H2O coordinated to the Ni cations, so that the Ni coordination changes from edge-sharing octahedral NiO5N to edge- and corner-sharing 5-fold NiO4N.  During this change, two out of three phosphonate groups rotate to become fully coordinated to Ni cations, leaving the remainder of the phosphonate groups coordinated to Ni cations by two O atoms and with a P=O bond projecting into the channels.  This transformation, which is completely reversible, causes substantial changes in both vibrational and electronic properties as shown by IR, Raman, and UV-visible spectroscopies.  Complementary adsorption, calorimetric, and IR studies of the probe adsorbates H2, CO, and CO2 reveal several distinct adsorption sites in the solid, which are attributed to their interactions with Ni cations which are weak Lewis acid sites, as well as with P=O groups that project into the pores.  At 304 K, the adsorption isotherms and enthalpies of adsorption on dehydrated Ni-STA-12 were measured for CO2 and CH4: Ni-STA-12 gives adsorption uptakes of CO2 of 2.5 mmol g-1 at 1 bar, an uptake ca.  10 Times that of CH4.
Highly Selective Ferric Ion Sorption and Exchange by Crystalline Metal Phosphonates Constructed from Tetraphosphonic Acids
Wu, Jie; Hou, Hongwei; Han, Huayun; Fan, Yaoting

With the motivation of searching for highly selective ferric ion sorbents, two open-framework and microporous materials, {[Pb7(HEDTP)2(H2O)]·7H2O}n (1) and {[Zn2(H4EDTP)]·2H2O}n (2) [H8EDTP = N,N,N',N'-ethylenediaminetetrakis(methylenephosphonic acid)], have been synthesized and structurally characterized.  The structure of compd. 1 results from the seven crystallog. different lead atoms that are bridged by two HEDTP7- ligands to yield a three-dimensional microporous framework with tunnels along the a and b axes.  Compd. 2 features a layer architecture built of square waves along the a axis.  The layers are connected by hydrogen bonds between uncoordinated phosphonate oxygen atoms to form a three-dimensional supramol. network, with one-dimensional tunnels along the a axis.  Both compds. 1 and 2 exhibited high ion sorption and exchange capacities for millimolar concns. of FeIII.  Specifically, when 0.01 g of 1 (or 2) was added to 5 mL of a 1 mM metallic chloride aq. soln. and the mixt. was allowed to stand for 2 days at room temp., compd. 1 adsorbed nearly 100% of FeIII and compd. 2 adsorbed 96.8% of FeIII.  They were also found to adsorb ferric ions selectively over other metal ions, such as CaII, CrII, MnII, CuII, ZnII, CdII, etc.  Their special ferric ion uptake capacities may be attributed to the cation exchange, coordination bonding, and electrostatic attraction between ferric ions and metal phosphonates.
Crystalline Zinc Diphosphonate Metal-Organic Framework with Three-Dimensional Microporosity
Liang, Junmei; Shimizu, George K. H.

While typically structures from linear diphosphonate ligands form dense phases, the authors report that with the functionalized ligand 1,4-dihydroxy-2,5-benzenediphosphonate (DHBP) and Zn2+ a microporous network is formed.  {[Zn(DHBP)](DMF)2} (1) possesses three-dimensional microporosity as shown by x-ray diffraction and confirmed by CO2 and N2 sorption studies.  Compd. 1 is composed of 1-dimensional columns of tetrahedral Zn ions with homoleptic phosphonate coordination.  This infinite building unit enables a robust and porous yet still cryst. material.
Synthesis and Characterization of the Open-Framework Barium Bisphosphonate [Ba3(O3PCH2NH2CH2PO3)2(H2O)4]·3H2O
Bauer, Sebastian; Mueller, Helen; Bein, Thomas; Stock, Norbert

Following the strategy of using polyfunctional phosphonic acids for the synthesis of open-framework metal phosphonates, the phosphonocarboxylic acid (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2C6H4COOH was used in the hydrothermal synthesis of a new barium phosphonate.  Its decompn. led to the first open-framework barium phosphonate, [Ba3(O3PCH2NH2CH2PO3)2(H2O)4]·3H2O (1).  The synthesis was also successfully performed using iminobis(methylphosphonic acid), (H2O3PCH2)2NH, as a starting material, and the synthesis was optimized to obtain 1 as a pure material.  The reaction setup as well as the pH are the dominant parameters, and only a diffusion-controlled reaction led to the desired compd. 1.  The crystal structure was solved from single-crystal data: monoclinic; space group C2/c; a 2328.7(2), b 1359.95(7), and c 718.62(6) pm; β 98.732(10)°; V = 2249.5(3) × 106 pm3; Z = 4; R1 = 0.036; and wR2 = 0.072 (all data).  The structure of [Ba3(O3PCH2NH2CH2PO3)2(H2O)4]·3H2O is built up from BaO8 and BaO10 polyhedra forming BaO chains and layers, resp.  These are connected to a three-dimensional metal-O-metal framework with the iminobis(methylphosphonate) formally coating the inner walls of the pores.  The 1-dimensional pores (3.6 × 4 Å) are filled with H2O mols. that can be thermally removed.  Thermogravimetric studies and temp.-dependent x-ray powder diffraction demonstrate the stability of the crystal structure up to 240°.  The uptake of DMF and H2O by dehydrated samples is demonstrated.  Also, IR, Raman, and 31P magic-angle-spinning NMR data are also presented.
The first route to large pore metal phosphonates
Groves, John A.; Miller, Stuart R.; Warrender, Stewart J.; Mellot-Draznieks, Caroline; Lightfoot, Philip; Wright, Paul A.

The 1st large pore (free diam. > 7 Å) metal phosphonates were prepd. as divalent transition metal N,N'-piperazinebis(methylenephosphonate)s that possess pores ⪆10 Å in free diam., are stable up to 400° and offer a route to chiral adsorbents and catalysts.  The prepn. and thermal decompn. of the analogous 2-methyl-N,N'-piperazinebis(methylenephosphonate)s is also reported.
A zeolite-like zinc phosphonocarboxylate framework and its transformation into two- and three-dimensional structures
Chen, Zhenxia; Zhou, Yaming; Weng, Linhong; Yuan, Chao; Zhao, Dongyuan

Zinc 4-phosphonobenzoates exhibit two- and three-dimensional self-assembly in the solid state, forming porous zeolite-like polymeric structure.  Three zinc 4-phosphonobenzoates, Zn2(pbc)2·Hdma·H3O·2H2O (1), Zn(pbc)·Hdma (2), and Zn4.5(pbc)3(OH)(H2O)0.5·Hdma [3; H3pbc = 4-(HO)2P(O)C6H4CO2H, dma = dimethylamine] were prepd. by the mixed solvothermal reaction of Zn(Ac)2·2H2O and 4-phosphonobenzoic acid in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and water.  The zigzag and ladder-like chains completely constructed by triply fused 4-membered rings (denoted SBU-1) are linked by the org. moieties to form the 3D zeolite-like structure 1 and the layered structure 2, resp.  As for structure 3, a new second building unit (SBU-2) formed by the inset of the [Zn3O12] trimer into the 4-membered ring as well as SBU-1 is obsd.  The connections between the two types of SBUs lead to a "zinc phosphate" layer, which is linked by the org. groups to generate a 3D pillar-layered structure.  Both soln.-mediated and solid-state transformations of 1 to 2 and 3 were obsd.  A possible mechanism for the transformation is proposed.  Gas sorption studies show that 1 has accessible pores for methanol and water and exhibits size selectivity for alcs.
Synthesis and structural characterisation of two new porous metal phosphonates: Zn(O3PCH2CO2H)·H2O and Pb(O3PCH:CH2)
Hix, G. B.; Turner, A.; Vahter, L.; Kariuki, B. M.

Changes in the synthetic procedures for prepg. metal phosphonate materials can lead to whole new structure types.  Using a eutectic mixt. of urea and choline chloride as the reaction medium for a reaction between Zn(OAc)2 and diethylphosphonacetic acid gives rise to Zn(O3PCH2CO2H)·H2O, which has a new porous structure.  Replacing divalent transition metal cations with Pb2+ in the synthesis of a vinylphosphonate, Pb(O3PCH=CH2), gives rise to a new porous structure that has not previously been obsd. for vinylphosphonates.  In this case it is the ability of the Pb2+ ions to adopt coordination environments other than octahedral or tetrahedral that allows the structure to form.
Chiral Lanthanide Complexes: Coordination Chemistry and Applications

A review is presented on the coordination chem. and applications of chiral lanthanide complexes.  Topics include the prepn. and structure of complexes with O- and N-donor ligands, mixed O/N-donors, macrocycles, helicates, and cyclopentadienyl and indenyl ligands, and their usage as NMR shift reagents and for enantioselective catalysis.
Taking advantage of luminescent lanthanide ions

Lanthanide ions possess fascinating optical properties and their discovery, first industrial uses and present high technological applications are largely governed by their interaction with light.  Lighting devices (economical luminescent lamps, light emitting diodes), television and computer displays, optical fibres, optical amplifiers, lasers, as well as responsive luminescent stains for biomedical analysis, medical diagnosis, and cell imaging rely heavily on lanthanide ions.  This critical review has been tailored for a broad audience of chemists, biochemists and materials scientists; the basics of lanthanide photophysics are highlighted together with the synthetic strategies used to insert these ions into mono- and polymetallic molecular edifices.  Recent advances in NIR-emitting materials, including liquid crystals, and in the control of luminescent properties in polymetallic assemblies are also presented. (210 references.).
Structures and luminescent properties of lanthanide phosphonates

A review.  The crystal structures and luminescent properties of lanthanide phosphonates are reviewed.  The structural elucidation for lanthanide phosphonates is difficult due to its low soly. and poor crystallinity.  To overcome these problems, two types of synthetic techniques were applied: attaching various functional groups or introducing a second metal linker.  By attaching various types of functional groups to the phosphonate ligand, lanthanide phosphonates with 0D, 1D, 2D and 3D structures have been isolated.  Using the acidic metal linker such as oxalate usually leads to compds. with a complicated 3D network structure whereas a basic second metal linker such as phenanthroline helps the formation of compds. contg. the polynuclear clusters.  Phosphonic acids are versatile ligands that can adopt a no. of coordination modes depending on the cation size, temp. and the pH value of the reaction media.  The luminescence properties of some lanthanide phosphonates are also discussed.
Anion-directed self-assembly of lanthanide-notp compounds and their fluorescence, magnetic, and catalytic properties
Bao, Song-Song; Ma, Li-Fang; Wang, Yin; Fang, Ling; Zhu, Cheng-Jian; Li, Yi-Zhi; Zheng, Li-Min

Reactions of 1,4,7-triazacyclononane-1,4,7-triyltris(methylenephosphonic acid) [notpH6, C9H18N3-(PO3H2)3] with different lanthanide salts result in four types of Ln-notp compds.: [Ln{C9H20N3(PO3H)2-(PO3)}(NO3)(H2O)]·4H2O (1), [Ln = Eu (1Eu), Gd (1Gd), Tb (1Tb)], [Ln-{C9H20N2(PO3H)2(PO3)}(H2O)]Cl·3H2O (2) [Ln = Eu (2Eu), Gd (2Gd), Tb (2Tb)], [Ln{C9H20N3(PO3H)2(PO3)}(H2O)]ClO4·8H2O, (3) [Ln = Eu (3Eu), Gd (3Gd)], and [Ln{C9H20N3-(PO3H)2(PO3)}(H2O)]ClO4·3H2O (4), [Ln = Gd (4Gd), Tb (4Tb)].  Compds. within each type are isostructural.  In compds. 1, dimers of {Ln2-(notpH4)2(NO3)2(H2O)2} are found, in which the two lanthanide atoms are connected by two pairs of O-P-O and one pair of μ-O bridges.  The NO3- ion serves as a bidentate terminal ligand.  Compds. 2 contain similar dimeric units of {Ln2(notpH4)2(H2O)2} that are further connected by a pair of O-P-O bridges into an alternating chain.  The Cl- ions are involved in the interchain H-bonding networks.  A similar chain structure is also found in compds. 3; in this case, however, the chains are linked by ClO4- counterions through H-bonding interactions, forming an undulating layer in the (011) plane.  These layers are fused through H-bonding interactions, leading to a three-dimensional supramol. network with large channels in the [100] direction.  Compds. 4 show an interesting brick-wall-like layer structure in which the neighboring lanthanide atoms are connected by a pair of O-P-O bridges.  The ClO4- counterions and the lattice H2O mols. are between the layers.  In all compds. the triazamacrocyclic N atoms are not coordinated to the LnIII ions.  The anions and the pH are believed to play key roles in directing the formation of a particular structure.  The fluorescence spectroscopic properties of the Eu and Tb compds., magnetic properties of the Gd compds., and the catalytic properties of 4Gd were also studied.
New types of blue, red or near IR luminescent phosphonate-decorated lanthanide oxalates

Hydrothermal reactions of the lanthanide chlorides with MeN(CH2CO2H)(CH2PO3H2), (H3L1) (or Me2NCH2PO3H2, H2L2) and Na oxalate lead to seven new lanthanide oxalate phosphonate hybrids with three types of 3-dimensional network structures, namely, [Ln(C2O4){MeNH(CH2CO2)(CH2PO3H)}]·0.5 H2O (Ln = Nd: 1; Eu: 2; Gd: 3), [Ln4(C2O4)5-(Me2NHCH2PO3)2(H2O)4]·2H2O (Ln = La: 4, Nd: 5), [Ln3(C2O4)4(Me2NHCH2PO3)(H2O)6]·6H2O (Gd: 6, Er: 7).  Their structures were established by x-ray single-crystal diffraction.  Complexes 1-3 are isostructural and feature a 3-dimensional network formed by the interconnection of 3-dimensional network of {Ln(H2L1)}2+ with 1-dimensional chains of {Ln(C2O4)}+.  Complexes 4 and 5 are isostructural and feature a complex 3-dimensional network built from 3-dimensional network of lanthanide oxalate and {Ln4(HL2)2} units.  The isostructural 6 and 7 form another type of 3-dimensional network composed of porous lanthanide-oxalate network inserted by 1-dimensional chains of lanthanide-oxalate phosphonate.  Compds. 1, 5 and 7 are luminescent materials in the near IR region.  Compds. 3 and 6 exhibit a broad blue fluorescent emission band at 451 and 467 nm, resp.  Compd. 2 displays very strong and sharp emission bands at 592, 616 and 699 nm with a long luminescent lifetime of 1.13 ms.
Introducing a Second Ligand: New Route to Luminescent Lanthanide Polyphosphonates

By introduction of oxalate as the second ligand, three novel luminescent lanthanide tetraphosphonates with two types of structures, namely, [La2(ox)2(H6L)]·2H2O (1, H8L = (H2O3PCH2)2NCH2CH2CH2CH2N(CH2PO3H2)2) and Ln2(ox)2(H6L)(H2O)2·4H2O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3), were prepd. and structurally characterized.  The interconnection of La(III) ions in 1 by bridging H6L anions resulted in a 3-dimensional network with tunnels running along the a-axis, the oxalate anions are located inside the above tunnels, and each forms two five-membered chelating rings with two La(III) ions.  All four phosphonate groups of the H6L anion are bidentate and singly protonated; its two amine groups are also protonated.  Compds. 2 and 3 are isostructural, and their structures feature a pillared layered structure.  The layer is formed by Ln(III) ions interconnected by oxalate and -NH(CH2PO3H)2 moieties of H6L anions, and the org. groups of the tetraphosphonate ligand act as the pillars.  Alternatively, their structures can be described as the lanthanide tetraphosphonate layers being cross-linked by oxalate anions (pillars).  The H6L anions in 2 and 3 are hexadentate, and each bridges with six Ln(III) ions; two phosphonate groups are bidentate, and the other two are unidentate.  Compds. 1, 2, and 3 exhibit strong emission bands in the blue, red light, and near-IR region, resp.
Lanthanide diruthenium(II,III) compounds showing layered and PtS-type open framework structures
Liu, Bin; Li, Bao-Long; Li, Yi-Zhi; Chen, Yu; Bao, Song-Song; Zheng, Li-Min

Two types of lanthanide diruthenium phosphonate compds., based on the mixed-valent metal-metal bonded paddle-wheel core of Ru2(hedp)23- [hedp = 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate, CH3C(OH)(PO3)2], were prepd.  Ln(H2O)4[Ru2(hedp)2(H2O)2].5.5H2O (1.Ln, Ln = La, Ce) and Ln(H2O)4[Ru2(hedp)2(H2O)2].8H2O (2.Ln, Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er).  In both types, each Ru2(hedp)2(H2O)23- unit is linked by four Ln3+ions through four phosphonate O (OP) atoms and vice versa.  The geometries of the {LnOP4} group, however, are different in the two cases.  In 1.Ln, the geometry of {LnOP4} is closer to a distorted plane, and thus a square-grid layer structure is found.  In 2.Ln, the geometry of {LnOP4} is better described as a distorted tetrahedron; hence, a unique PtS-type open-framework structure is obsd.  The channels generated in structures 2.Ln are filled with H2O aggregates with extensive H-bond interactions.  The magnetic and electrochem. properties are also studied.
Three-dimensional lanthanide(III)-copper(II) compounds based on an unsymmetrical 2-pyridylphosphonate ligand: an experimental and theoretical study
Ma, Yun-Sheng; Li, Hui; Wang, Jun-Jie; Bao, Song-Song; Cao, Rong; Li, Yi-Zhi; Ma, Jing; Zheng, Li-Min

Based on an unsym. 2-pyridylphosphonate ligand, two types of LnIII-CuII compds. with three-dimensional structures were obtained under hydrothermal conditions, namely, Ln2Cu3(C5H4NPO3)6·4H2O (1·Ln; Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd) and Ln2Cu3(C5H4NPO3)6 (2·Ln; Ln = Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho).  Compds. 1·Ln are isostructural and crystallize in chiral cubic space group I213.  In these structures, each Ln ion is nine-coordinate and has a tricapped triprismatic geometry, while each Cu center is six-coordinate with an octahedral environment.  The {LnO9} polyhedra and {CuN2O4} octahedra are connected by edge sharing to form an inorg. open framework structure with a 3-connected 10-gon (10,3) topol. in which the Ln and Cu atoms are alternately linked by the phosphonate oxygen atoms.  Compds. 2·Ln are isostructural and crystallize in trigonal space group R‾3.  In these structures, the {LnO6} octahedra are triply bridged by the {CPO3} tetrahedra by corner sharing to form an infinite chain along the c axis.  Each chain is connected to its six equiv. through corner sharing of {CPO3} tetrahedra and {CuN2O2} planes to form a three-dimensional framework structure in which the Ln and Cu atoms are linked purely by O-P-O units.  The formation of these two types of structures is rationalized by quantum chem. calcns., which showed that both the lanthanide contraction and the electron configuration of CuII play important roles.  When CuII was replaced by ZnII, only the first type of compds. resulted.  The magnetic properties of complexes 1·Ln and 2·Ln were investigated.  The nature of LnIII-CuII (Ln = Ce, Pr, Nd) interactions is illustrated by comparison with their LnIII-ZnII analogs.
Chiral porous solids based on lamellar lanthanide phosphonates
Evans, Owen R.; Ngo, Helen L.; Lin, Wenbin
Journal of the American Chemical Society

The synthesis, structure, chiral sepn., and catalytic properties were investigated of homochiral porous lamellar lanthanide bisphosphonates.  The bisphosphonates [Ln(H2L)(H3L)(H2O)4].xH2O (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, Tb; x = 9-14; H4L = 2,2'-diethoxy-1,1'-binaphthalene-6,6'-bisphosphonic acid) were synthesized by slow evapn. of an acidic mixt. of Ln(III) salts and H4L in methanol at RT.  A preliminary attempt at the enantioselective sepn. of racemic trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane only gave limited sepn.  However, with a precise knowledge of their single-crystal structures and facile tunability of their building blocks, the present materials hold great promise in the development of novel chiral porous materials capable of sepn. and catalysis with practically useful enantioselectivity.
Two Closely Related Lanthanum Phosphonate Frameworks Formed by Anion-Directed Linking of Inorganic Chains
Groves, John A.; Wright, Paul A.; Lightfoot, Philip

Two novel three-dimensional La coordination polymers were prepd. with the phosphonic acid H2O3PCH2N(C2H4)2NCH2PO3H2 (LH4). La2(LH2)2(LH4)Cl2 (I) and La2(LH2)2(LH3)Cl (II) arise from similar hydrothermal reactions but differing sources of La.  A 1-dimensional La-phosphate chain, comprising corner-linked LaO7 and PO3C polyhedra, forms the basis for the two different structures.  The two structures differ in the mode of connectivity of the inorg. chains via the phosphonate groups.  Both materials include extra framework chloride ions, the different amts. of which apparently direct the polytypic structures.  In II, the chloride ions are incorporated in a noncentrosym. manner leading to a polar framework topol.
Novel open-framework architectures in lanthanide phosphonates
Groves, John A.; Stephens, Nicholas F.; Wright, Paul A.; Lightfoot, Philip

Two novel three-dimensional lanthanide coordination polymers have been prepd. hydrothermally with the phosphonic acid N,N'-piperazinebis(methylenephosphonic acid), H2O3PCH2N(C2H4)2NCH2PO3H2 (LH4).  The structures of Gd2(LH2)3·3H2O (1) and Nd2(LH2)3·9H2O (2) have been characterized by single crystal X-ray techniques.  One-dimensional lanthanide phosphate chains are a key feature in both structures although there are major structural differences between the chains with 1 displaying octahedral GdO6 coordination and 2 showing eight-coordinate NdO8 polyhedra.  In each case three-dimensional connectivity is completed by coordination of the phosphonate group resulting in open framework structures encapsulating loosely bound water mols.  Isostructural Y3+ and Yb3+ analogs of 1 have been prepd. suggesting that cation size is a key factor in controlling the differing reaction products.  In the case of Y2(LH2)3·5H2O which is isostructural to 1 it is shown that the extra-framework water mols. may be removed reversibly without framework collapse.  Structural relationships to other known lanthanide phosphonates are discussed.
Rational Design of 0D, 1D, and 3D Open Frameworks Based on Tetranuclear Lanthanide(III) Sulfonate-Phosphonate Clusters
Du, Zi-Yi; Xu, Hai-Bing; Mao, Jiang-Gao

Hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) salts with m-sulfophenylphosphonic acid (H3L1) and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) or N,N'-piperazinebis(methylenephosphonic acid) (H4L2) afforded six novel lanthanide(III) sulfonate-phosphonates based on tetranuclear clusters, namely, [La2(L1)2(phen)4(H2O)]·4.5H2O (1), [Ln2(L1)2(phen)2(H2O)5]·3H2O (Ln = Nd, 2; Eu, 3; Er, 4), and [Ln2(HL1)(H2L2)2(H2O)4]·8H2O (Ln = La, 5; Nd, 6).  Compds. 2-4 contain discrete tetranuclear lanthanide(III) cluster units in which four lanthanide(III) ions are bridged by two tridentate and two tetradentate phosphonate groups.  In compd. 1 the tetranuclear clusters are further interconnected into a 1D chain through the coordination of the sulfonate groups.  The structures of compds. 5 and 6 can be viewed as a 3D architecture based on a different types of tetranuclear cluster units that are interconnected by bridging H2L2 anions.  In the tetranuclear clusters of compds. 5 and 6 the four lanthanide(III) centers are interconnected by only two HL1 ligands.  Compd. 2 is a luminescent material in the near-IR region whereas compd. 3 displays a strong luminescent emission band in the red-light region.  Magnetic property measurements of compds. 2-4 and 6 indicate that there are strong antiferromagnetic interactions between magnetic centers within the cluster units.
Novel polymeric metal complexes of calix[4]arene-11,23-diphosphonic acid: synthesis and structure determination
Plutnar, Jan; Rohovec, Jan; Kotek, Jan; Zak, Zdirad; Lukes, Ivan

New calixarene derivs. bearing two phosphonic acid groups, 25,27-dimethoxy-26,28-dihydroxycalix[4]arene-11,23-diphosphonic acid (3) and its tetra-Et ester (2) were synthesized.  Their x-ray structures confirmed cone conformation of the mols., more deformed for the ester due to bulky Et groups.  Complexes [CaH2L(MeOH)2]·4MeOH (4) and [NdH2L(NO3)(H2O)2]·2H2O·2MeOH (5, H4L = 26,28-dihydroxy-25,27-dimethoxycalix[4]arene-11,23-diphosphonic acid) were also prepd.  Structures of 4 and 5 were detd. by x-ray anal.  The structural motif of 4 is similar to that found for the free acid 3.  The calixarenes are linked by coordination of phosphonates to Ca(II) in a polymeric structure instead of a network of hydrogen bonds in 3.  Structure of 5 is different: four calixarene mols. are linked through coordination to Nd(III) in a supramol. macroring, which forms a pore (∼17 Å in diam.) penetrating through the structure.
Synthesis and Characterization of a New Three-Dimensional Lanthanide Carboxyphosphonate: Ln4(H2O)7[O2C-C5H10N-CH2-PO3]4(H2O)5
Serre, Christian; Stock, Norbert; Bein, Thomas; Ferey, Gerard

The 1st open-framework lanthanide carboxyphosphonate was obtained under hydrothermal conditions.  The three-dimensional structure of MIL-84Pr (MIL = Material Institut Lavoisier) or Pr4(H2O)7[O2C-C5H10N-CH2-PO3]4(H2O)5 was solved from x-ray diffraction single-crystal data (a 23.481(1), b 10.159(1), c 23.006(1) Å, β 105.63(1)°, V = 5284.6(6) Å3, space group Cc (No. 9)).  Its framework is built up from chains of edged-sharing eight or nine-coordinated monocapped square antiprism polyhedra and carboxyphosphonate anions, creating a three-dimensional structure with small pores filled with H2O mols.  The thermal behavior of MIL-84Pr was studied using TGA and x-ray thermodiffractometry and indicates that MIL-84Pr is stable up to 523 K with a reversible hydration-dehydration process.  The optical study of its Y analog doped at 3.4% with Eu (MIL-84(Y,Eu)) reveals a significant red-orange emission under UV radiation.
Luminescent Lanthanide(III) Carboxylate-Phosphonates with Helical Tunnels
Tang, Si-Fu; Song, Jun-Ling; Li, Xiu-Ling; Mao, Jiang-Gao

Hydrothermal reactions of lanthanide(III) salts with H4PMIDA (N-(phosphonomethyl)iminodiacetic acid) led to seven new isostructural lanthanide(III) carboxylate phosphonates, namely, Ln(HPMIDA)(H2O)2·H2O (Ln = Gd, 1; Tb, 2; Dy, 3; Y, 4; Er, 5; Yb, 6; Lu, 7).  Their structures feature a novel 3-dimensional framework.  The lanthanide(III) ion is eight-coordinated by a chelating HPMIDA in a tetradentate fashion (1 N and 3 O), one carboxylate O and one phosphonate O from two other HPMIDA anions, and two aqua ligands.  The HPMIDA anion is hexadentate.  It chelates with a Ln(III) ion in a tetradentate manner and also bridges with two other Ln(III) ions.  The phosphonate group is singly protonated.  One of the carboxylic groups is unidentate, whereas the other is bidentate bridging.  Compd. 2 exhibits very strong characteristic emission bands for the Tb(III) ion in the visible region under 380 nm excitation, with the Tb (5D0) lifetime for λex,em = 380 and 488 nm being ∼1 ms.  Compds. 1 and 5 display very broad ligand-centered emission bands in the blue light region.
Homochiral Porous Lanthanide Phosphonates with 1D Triple-Strand Helical Chains: Synthesis, Photoluminescence, and Adsorption Properties
Yue, Qi; Yang, Jin; Li, Guang-Hua; Li, Guo-Dong; Chen, Jie-Sheng

Four homochiral porous lanthanide phosphonates, [Ln(H2L)3]·2H2O, (H3L = (S)-HO3PCH2-NHC4H7-CO2H, N-phosphonomethyl-L-proline) Ln = Tb (1), Dy (2), Eu (3), Gd (4), were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions.  These compds. are isostructural, and they possess a 3-dimensional supramol. framework built up from 1-dimensional triple-strand helical chains.  Each of the helical chain consists of phosphonate groups bridging adjacent Ln(III) ions.  The helical chains are stacked through H bonds to form 1-dimensional tubular channels along the c axis.  Also, helical H2O chains are located in the 1-dimensional channels, and after removal of these H2O chains, the compds. exhibit selective adsorption capacities for N2, H2O, and MeOH mols.  1 And 3 show strong green and red fluorescent emissions, resp., in the solid state at room temp.  Crystal data for 1: TbP3O17N3C18H37, tetragonal (No.76), space group P41, a 12.4643(3), b 12.4643(3), c 18.7577(5) Å, and Z = 4; 2: DyP3O17N3C18H37, a 12.4486(3), b 12.4486(3), c 18.7626(5) Å, V = 2907.60(13) Å3, and Z = 4; 3: EuP3O17N3C18H37, a 12.4799(3), b 12.4799(3), c 18.8239(5) Å, V = 2931.78(13) Å3, and Z = 4; 4: GdP3O17N3C18H37, a 12.4877(18), b 12.4877(18), c 18.824(4) Å, V = 2935.5(8) Å3, and Z = 4.
Synthesis, Structural Characterization, and Luminescence Properties of Lanthanide Oxalatophosphonates: Na[M3(H2O)4(C2O4)4(CH3PO3)]·2H2O (M = Nd and Pr)
Huang, Ya-Ling; Huang, Meow-Yu; Chan, Tsung-Han; Chang, Bor-Chen; Lii, Kwang-Hwa

A neodymium oxalatophosphonate and its praseodymium analog, Na[Nd3(H2O)4(C2O4)4(CH3PO3)]·2H2O and Na[Pr3(H2O)4(C2O4)4(CH3PO3)]·2H2O, were synthesized by a hydrothermal method and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction and TGA.  The authors studied the photoluminescence spectra of the Nd and Pr compds. as well as the magnetic properties of the Nd compd.  The structure consists of layers built of tetramers of edge- and face-sharing NdO9 (or PrO9) polyhedra connected by oxalate and methylphosphonate units, which are linked by zigzag infinite chains of oxalate-bridged NdO9 (or PrO9) polyhedra to form a 3-dimensional framework.  They are the 1st examples of lanthanide oxalate-methylphosphonate.  The Nd compd. displays characteristic emission bands in the near IR region.  The χMT value decreases from 1.68 cm3 K/mol Nd at 300 K to 0.659 cm3 K/mol Nd at 2 K.  The value at room temp. is close to the theor. value for a mononuclear Nd3+ species.  Luminescence of the Pr compd. consists of many emission bands at 480-760 nm.  The lifetimes of both compds. are much shorter than the expected values because of the quenching effects of water mols. in the structure.  Crystal data for the Nd compd.: triclinic, space group P‾1, a 9.0682(2), b 9.5114(3), c 14.0066(4) Å, α 74.975(2), β 86.534(2), γ 82.725(2)°, and Z = 2.  Crystal data for the Pr compd. are the same as those for the Nd compd., except a 9.125(1), b 9.549(1), c 14.073(2) Å, α 75.086(2), β 86.611(2), and γ 82.545(2)°.
Synthesis and structure of the phosphonocarboxylic acid H2O3PCH2-NC5H9-COOH·2H2O and the manganese phosphonocarboxylate Mn[O3PCH2-N(H)C5H9-COO]
Stock, N.; Karaghiosoff, K.; Bein, T.
Zeitschrift fuer Anorganische und Allgemeine Chemie

N-phosphonomethylpiperidine-4-carboxylic acid, H2O3PCH2-NC5H9-COOH·2H2O (1), was synthesized by a Mannich-type reaction.  Recrystn. from hydrochloric acid yields large single crystals (crystal data for 1: monoclinic, space group P21/n, a 6.4011(3), b 25.633(2), c 7.2496(4) Å, β = 95.473(7), Z = 4).  In an aq. soln. two isomers of 1 were unambiguously detected by NMR-spectroscopy.  The reaction of 1 with manganese chloride under hydrothermal conditions at pH 5 yields the new manganese phosphonocarboxylate Mn[O3PCH2-N(H)C5H9-COO] (2) that was characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction (crystal data for 2: monoclinic, space group P21/a, a 10.2784(2), b 9.0649(2), c 11.0712(2) Å, β 107.280(1)°, Z = 4).  In 1, zwitterions HO3PCH2-N(H)C5H9-COOH and H2O mols. are interconnected by O-H···O and N-H···O hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional network.  In 2, corner-linked MnO5 and PO3C polyhedra form four- and eight-rings which are connected to a two-dimensional net.  The coordination of the carboxylate ions, which act as chelating ligands, leads to a pillared structure.

Metal phosphonates based on (4-carboxypiperidyl)-N-methylenephosphonate: in-situ ligand cleavage and metamagnetism in Co3(O3PCH2-NHC5H9-COO)2(O3PCH2-NC5H10)(H2O)
Hou, Shou-Zeng; Cao, Deng-Ke; Liu, Xun-Gao; Li, Yi-Zhi; Zheng, Li-Min

Hydrothermal reaction of 4-carboxypiperidyl-N-methylenephosphonic acid (4-cpmpH3) and zinc sulfate results in compd. Zn(O3PCH2-NHC5H9-COO) (1) which was characterized by X-ray crystallog.  It has a pillared layered structure in which the inorg. layers made up of corner-sharing {CPO3} and {ZnO4} tetrahedra are connected by the org. groups.  When cobalt sulfate is allowed to react with 4-cpmpH3 under similar conditions, a proportion of the ligands undergo decarboxylation, leading to the formation of a novel mixed ligated compd. Co3(O3PCH2-NHC5H9-COO)2(O3PCH2-NC5H10)(H2O) (2), also characterized by X-ray crystallog.  Compd. 2 also shows a pillared layered structure with the topol. of the inorg. layer similar to that of 1.  The CoII ions in 2 are all tetrahedrally coordinated.  Significant difference between the two structures lies in the packing of the layers, e.g., AAA in 1 while AABAAB in 2.  More interestingly, compd. 2 behaves as a metamagnet at low temp.  The crit. field is 40.1 kOe at 1.8 K.
Two 3D Porous Lanthanide-Fumarate-Oxalate Frameworks Exhibiting Framework Dynamics and Luminescent Change upon Reversible De- and Rehydration
Zhu, Wen-Hua; Wang, Zhe-Ming; Gao, Song

The authors present two porous luminescent compds., [Ln2(fumarate)2(oxalate)(H2O)4]·4H2O (Ln = Eu, Tb), prepd. by the hydrothermal method.  The materials have 3-dimensional framework structure consisting of oxalate pillared lanthanide-fumarate layers with intersected channels occupied by guest H2O.  They exhibit framework dynamics upon several cycles of dehydration and rehydration.  The crystallinity of the as-prepd. hydrated materials degrades completely to the amorphous dehydrated phases, while it returns upon rehydration.  A mechanism for de-/rehydration is proposed from the structure and spectroscopic data.  The dehydration process is accompanied by the lost of luminescence of Ln ion, but the luminescence is recovered upon rehydration, where H2O mols. in fact enhance the luminescence but not quench it.  This is probably due to the softened environment of lanthanide ion in the dehydrated amorphous phases and the recovery of the stiffness after rehydration.
